content: The "Independent Counsel Reauthorization Act of 1993" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, by extending the reauthorization period to five years. Added controls are also included in the Act. The "Independent Counsel Reauthorization Act of 1993" amends Section 594 of title 28, United States Code by adding new subsections related to cost controls and administrative support for independent counsels. An independent counsel must conduct activities with regard for expense, authorize reasonable expenditures, and assign an employee to certify expenditures. Compliance with Department of Justice policies is required. The Independent Counsel Reauthorization Act of 1993 requires independent counsels to comply with Department of Justice policies on expenditures. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts provides administrative support and guidance, while the Administrator of General Services assists with office space. The Independent Counsel Reauthorization Act of 1993 mandates that independent counsels receive appropriate office space within a Federal building. They are also entitled to travel expenses as per specified regulations. The Independent Counsel Reauthorization Act of 1993 mandates that independent counsels receive office space in a Federal building and travel expenses according to specific regulations. Independent counsels and appointed individuals are not eligible for travel expenses after one year of service unless certified as in the public interest. The certification for travel and subsistence expenses of independent counsels can be renewed every 6 months if the employee makes a recertification. Factors considered include the cost to the Government and the anticipated duration of activities. The certification for travel and subsistence expenses of independent counsels can be renewed every 6 months if the employee makes a recertification. Factors considered include the personal and financial burdens of relocating and appointing a new independent counsel. An employee making a certification or recertification shall be liable for an invalid certification to the same extent as a certifying official certifying a voucher. Additionally, ethics enforcement is emphasized in Section 594(j) with the Attorney General and the Director of the Office of Government Ethics having authority to enforce compliance. The independent counsel must prepare annual expenditure statements by December 31, with audits conducted by the Comptroller General and reported to relevant congressional committees by March 31 of the following year. SEC. 4. MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. Section 591(c) of title 28, United States Code is amended to allow the Attorney General to conduct preliminary investigations, including for Members of Congress if there are grounds to investigate potential violations of Federal law. The Attorney General can conduct preliminary investigations for Members of Congress if there are grounds to investigate potential violations of Federal law, excluding Class B or C misdemeanors or infractions. The amendments to title 28, United States Code, allow for the removal of individuals due to physical or mental disability, in accordance with anti-discrimination laws. The effective date of these amendments is upon enactment of the Act.
